Stop us if you’ve heard this: cryptocurrencies are experiencing an unprecedented boom, and have become a convenient replacement for conventional cash. But did you know that ETH, one of the biggest crypto assets in circulation, is far more interesting that you though, and it might be a good idea to learn more about this digital coin, because by the looks of it Ethereum is just beginning to blossom.

So what is Ethereum? Technically, Ethereum is not the name of the cryptocurrency but namesake of the distribution software platform that is based on blockchain tech. ETH, or ether, is the platform’s native cryptocurrency, which is bought and sold within the blockchain’s matrix, and even though ETH is the supporting asset of the Ethereum network (it services the apps built within Ethereum ), many other digital coins can be used within Ethereum’s ecosystem. Interactions within the network of Ethereum are called “transactions”

A defining feature of Ethereum is its limitless supply brough about by its inherent nature: it is a serviceable token designed as a practical assets as well as one that can bring in profit, without the risk of inflation decreasing or increasing its value.

The Ethereum platform is spread on computers all around the world, in what is consider a “decentralized” network – otherwise referred to as the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) – , in which users are active life supporters, or “nodes”, essentially enabling the network to become immune to any sort of disruptive attacks or otherwise. The case can be summed up with the maxim “the whole is better than the one”; as one computer shuts down due to benevolent actors, the Ethereum network remains virtually unscathed as thousands of other machines keep all systems up.

Ethereum came to be after Vitalik Buterin, of Russian-Canadian descent, started to notice flaws in Bitcoin’s operations. More like shortcoming, Vitalik decided to build upon the Bitcoin ideal by expanding on its capabilities but at the same time focusing on his own project that would later become Ethereum.

Initially in 2013 Vitalik came up with the idea of smart contracts – a programing method based on the fundamental axiom of “if x, then y “- that completely revolutionized decentralized operations by allowing just about anyone with a capable machine and computational knowledge to develop decentralized application within the Ethereum 1.0 network.

While decentralized apps, or DApps, already existed, Buterin aimed to unify them under the same banner, that of Ethereum. A DApp is a program that runs on blockchain ware or a peer-to-peer network completely open-source under no one’s jurisdiction, making is, essentially, decentralized. DApps can be any number of applications, from standards games to social media outlets, to utilizing and storing NFTs, and everything in between. Of course, the main usage of Ethereum’s platform is to act as a payment mediator between transaction parties.

In Ethereum 1.0 there are no rules as there is no hierarchy of power to enforce inside regulations and control. Instead, all those individual “nodes” hold the power, shifting the governance system within Ethereum 1.0 into one of a pure democracy. Ether is the backbone of these operations, the currency that allows all processes to function within a certain consensus-based framework.

One of Ethereum’s biggest use is to create the so-called “smart contracts’. It’s what separates this crypto asset’s environment from others, and is the “secret sauce” 0f the ETH network. Smart contracts are standardized systems within Ethereum that enable various processes to function and run smoothly. It’s essentially an automated agreement that runs of four foundational pillars:

A cryptographic voucher system enabling the creation of various systems and assets to be built on pre-existing blockchains.

Peer-to-peer capabilities that form the matrix of ETH system-running computers, scratching the need for a central server. Most cryptocurrencies run on P2P networks.

Consensus algorithms acting as decision making apparatus for the ETH blockchain, with every 15 seconds marking the endorsement of a new consent, generally one having to do with the addition of new blocks to be added to the blockchain tech.

The Turing virtual machine allows for complex and demanding processes to be smoothly performed on the ETH network, in turn increasing Ethereum’s ability to handle “heavier” programs.

Ethereum is arguably the most advantageous of all crypto assets, with millions of users relying on it as a means of digital transfers. With Ethereum 2.0 coming (pilot phases have already been launched), this massively successful crypto system has deserved its spot as Bitcoin’s main competition. ETH adoption has spread like wild fire, and many want in on the action. That’s why big brokerage companies have rallied their engineers, their system administrators, and payment operators, all in the effort to make Ether a payment method.
